name: Up, Close and Centre
description:
Airavata, Indra's divine elephant, draws water from the underworld and creates clouds that become rain. Anand Sachin from the MAP team dives into this story in Up, Close and Centre: In Celestial Company.

MAP is home to a growing collection of over 100,000 artworks. Up, Close & Centre is a series that allows audiences to engage with art in deeper and more meaningful ways by delving into the context, narratives and makings of one artwork from our collection, chosen by our team members.

name: Access Tour: Experiencing MAP's Inclusive Design
description:
“Inclusive design” isn't just a buzzword, it's built into our walls.

While most of our guided walks focus on exhibitions, this session offers something different—a chance to explore how the MAP building is designed to be inclusive and accessible for everyone. This one-hour walkthrough will be led by Inclusion Manager Shailesh Kulal, who will share firsthand perspectives on accessibility and inclusive design.

This event is part of our International Day of Persons with Disabilities (IDPD) celebrations, running from December 6, 2025 onwards at MAP. The programme celebrates diverse abilities and aims to raise awareness, promote accessibility, and create inclusive environments in workplaces and communities.

name: A Mughal Songbook: Art, Music and Empire
description:
The songbook of Sophia Elizabeth Plowden, with lyrics of Rekhtah ghazal by Asaf al-Dawlah, Nawab of Avadh and Punjabi tappah, ink, opaque watercolours, and gold on paper, Lucknow, India, 1787-88, © Fitzwilliam Museum Cambridge.
A Mughal Songbook: Art, Music and Empire, is an upcoming display at the Fitzwilliam Museum in Cambridge. It reveals the intricate pages of the Plowden songbook, which is a book that gave rise to a cross-cultural appreciation of Hindustani music. 

Containing seventy-seven songs written in Persian, Urdu, Classical Hindi, and Punjabi, this manuscript oﬀers a window into the visual and performing arts of late Mughal South Asia, illuminating the relationships between singers, dancers, courtesans, poets, and the books and objects they cherished. 

At the core of A Mughal Songbook is the story of Sophia Elizabeth Plowden (1751–1834), and her exquisite book of lyrics and music notation, dated 1787–88. In it, Plowden recorded and illustrated the music she encountered in North Indian courtly gatherings during a period of transition between the Mughal and British Empires. 

The Plowden songbook ultimately gave rise to the colonial phenomenon of ‘Hindustani Airs’ – Hindustani songs adapted and performed by British elites on the harpsichord. This talk will give audiences a sneak peek at this upcoming exhibition and re-enliven the sensory world of Islamic and South Asian art, evoking the sounds, images, and textures emerging from late Mughal culture.

This event is in collaboration with Art, Resources and Teaching Trust.

name: Family Day - Third Edition
description:
The year is wrapping up, and we're celebrating with events the whole family will love. End 2025 on a high note with us! Make memories with your family at our festive lineup of events.

Bring your children, nieces and nephews, grandkids and godchildren for a fun-filled day of learning, games, and activities. From hearing stories across the museum and treasure hunts, to playful activities in our exhibitions, the day is packed with events designed especially for children. Wrap up the experience with a delightful theatre performance for young audiences. We’ve got the whole day sorted—all you need is a child (or a few!) to join in. The more, the merrier!



 

Quality Time with Rhythm n Rhyme (Ages 1 to 5)

10:00-11:00 AM  (Session 1)
1:00-2:00 PM      (Session 2)

Bring your toddler or young child (up to 6 years) for an hour of dancing, singing, and interactive fun—parents can join in too!

Bob the Builder with Troy World (Ages 6 to 10)

11:30 AM - 12:30 PM  (Session 1)
2:30 PM - 3:30 PM    (Session 2)

Build, stack, create! With Troy World's wooden blocks, kids can construct sky-high giraffes, roaring dinosaurs, or anything their imagination dreams up.

Journey Through the Realms (Ages 8 to 12)

11:00 AM - 12:00 PM (Session 1)
1:00-2:00 PM              (Session 2)

Travel through the five realms of air, land, water, the in-between and the celestial, and discover what each companion reveals about deities, the world, and our lives. 

Bond Through Sign Language (All ages)

12:00 PM-1:00 PM

Join our Indian Sign Language session for beginners hosted by Madhur Arora from the MAP team. Learn words in sign language related to family, art, culture and more.

The Great Tikat Hunt (8 to 15)

10:00 AM - 3:00 PM

Unleash your inner detective as you embark on a thrilling quest to find hidden clues scattered throughout the exhibition Ticket Tika Chaap. Are you ready to take on the challenge? Let the hunt begin!

Crabbby by Ranga Shankara’s AHA! (All ages)

3:00-4:00 PM

Directed by S. Surendranath, this story follows Crabby and Storky, enemies turned friends, as they come together to rescue their pond. When townspeople keep throwing garbage into their home, Crabby comes up with a brilliant idea to save it. From Ranga Shankara's AHA!, this show is for everyone- from cute battanis to cool colony uncles!!

Pause and Play (5 to 15)

11:00AM - 3:00PM

A family activity zone to slow down, make, and share time together. Hop between stations for colouring, crafting clay dolls or pebble painting. 

Face Art Fun (5 to 15)

11:00AM - 3:00PM

Transform little faces into works of art! Parents and guardians can use skin-safe colors to create designs together at the face painting station.

Bringing You Stories! (All ages)

10:15 - 11:00 AM (Session 1)
12:15 - 1:00 PM   (Session 2)
2:00 - 2:45 PM   (Session 3)

Follow the voices! Kathalaya Storytellers are scattered across the museum, ready to whisk you away to magical places. Perfect for making new family memories while reliving old ones.

Please note that some events have limited capacity per session, but multiple time slots are available so everyone has a chance to participate! Here is a list of FAQS for the queries you may have.

name: Kalaripayattu
description:
Image credits: Arun
The exhibition, In Celestial Company, celebrates divine helpers and wondrous animals and this event explores how deeply connected we are to the natural world.

Kalaripayattu, an ancient Indian martial art, takes inspiration from the movements of animals, such as the snake, horse, peacock, elephant and more. By observing and mimicking nature, this practice has influenced our cultures and way of life for centuries.

Join movement artist Chandramohan for a lecture demonstration where he'll show how animal movements in Kalari develop grounding, alertness, intuition, and strength, highlighting the art's beautiful connection with nature and balance.

This event is in conjunction with In Celestial Company exhibition programming.

name: Human Library – Featuring Artists with Disabilities
description:
Meet artists up close in an intimate setting. The Human Library is a unique format where artists share their practice for a few minutes, then open the floor for your questions and conversation.

The Human Library invites you to meet artists Gayatri Gupta, Jyoti K Kumar and Nawaz Shaikh, who will share their creative journeys, artistic perspectives, and the stories behind their practice. This is a conversation about art, inspiration, and creative process—foregrounding the work, not the disability.

This event is part of our International Day of Persons with Disabilities (IDPD) celebrations, running from December 6, 2025 onwards at MAP. The programme celebrates diverse abilities and aims to raise awareness, promote accessibility, and create inclusive environments in workplaces and communities.
